context_text:
## Technical Post-Mortem Report

### 1. Problem Statement
A Japan-based user reported inability to locate FTA (Free Trade Agreement) eligibility checking fields in the SALES CONTRACT system, following a Thailand-India case where incorrect WisE master FTA registration resulted in unnecessary import tax payments. The inquiry was part of a global investigation to verify proper FTA registration for export country parts in the WisE master system.

### 2. Solution Summary
The issue was resolved by clarifying that FTA information is entered through the EPA field in Sales Contract rather than in WisE, with both FPA and COO registration available by item number.

### 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• User submitted inquiry about missing FTA eligibility fields in SALES CONTRACT system with reference to WISE FTA application procedures
• Case escalated to OP Team for technical investigation
• Technical analysis confirmed FTA information entry location is EPA field in Sales Contract, not WisE system
• Initial response provided to user identifying EPA field as correct location for FTA data entry
• User requested clarification on EPA definition and field verification using attached JPG screenshot
• Final technical clarification provided explaining EPA as tariff-related regulation with capability to register both FPA and COO by item number

### 4. Key Findings
• FTA information entry is handled through EPA field in Sales Contract system, not WisE
• EPA field supports manual entry without automated validation
• System supports registration of both FPA and COO data by item number
• No standardized manual exists for FTA application procedures in the system

### 5. Final Status & Recommendations
The case was successfully resolved with user receiving correct field location and functionality explanation. The organization should consider developing comprehensive documentation for FTA/EPA field usage and implementing standardized procedures to prevent future WisE master registration errors that result in unnecessary import tax payments.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Good question and RAG answer keyword coverage, supports ground truth keywords

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement
Customer needed guidance on confirming and registering FTA (Free Trade Agreement) information in the WisE system for parts exported to Thailand and Vietnam that require certificates of origin for preferential treatment.

## 2. Solution Summary
The support team clarified that FTA information is managed through EPA Master functionality in WisE as reference fields only, without special FTA management functions.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• Customer inquiry received regarding FTA registration confirmation and setup procedures in WisE master
• Support team escalated inquiry to technical operations team for investigation
• Technical team analyzed WisE system capabilities for FTA/EPA functionality
• Team identified that WisE uses EPA Master instead of dedicated FTA functions
• Support provided system navigation guidance to EPA Master location in WisE interface
• Team explained EPA Type Code input process in Contract Part Info section
• Support clarified that EPA Type Code serves as reference field without affecting WisE workflows
• Follow-up questions sent to customer requesting specific information requirements and document needs

## 4. Key Findings
• FTA functionality exists only as reference fields in WisE system
• No dedicated FTA management functions available in WisE
• EPA Master serves as the primary tool for managing preferential trade agreement data
• EPA Type Code can be entered in Contract Part Info during contract creation/modification
• EPA codes function as reference only and do not alter WisE business processes

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations
The ticket was resolved with status "Solved." The customer was provided with clear navigation instructions for accessing EPA Master functionality and guidance on inputting EPA Type Codes. The support team recommended the customer specify their exact information requirements and identify which WisE documents need to display FTA information for any additional customization needs.

## 6. Business Terminology Retained
- WisE (system name)
- FTA registration
- EPA Master
- EPA Type Code
- Contract Part Info
- Certificates of origin
- Preferential treatment

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement

Toyota Tsusho Vietnam requested to receive Purchase Orders (POs) from WisE system with import duty tax rates automatically reflected, similar to their ID-Part sourcing process. Currently, their accounting team must manually allocate import tax rates when recording shipments in the WEST system due to missing duty rate information in POs generated from their TH sourcing contract part route (VNTBH001).

## 2. Solution Summary

WisE system does not maintain Import Tax Rate master data and only sends Contract master to WEST during interface, requiring import duty tax rates to be configured directly in the WEST system's Purchase Order process.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Customer submitted inquiry with contract details (Purchase contract SGTVNH006, Order No. THVN00028A) and provided reference invoices comparing ID-Part vs TH-Part sourcing processes
• Support team escalated inquiry to OP Team for technical investigation
• Investigation conducted to determine WisE system capabilities regarding import tax rate handling
• WEST team documentation retrieved explaining import duty tax rate configuration process
• Solution provided directing customer to configure import tax rates directly in WEST PO using Material master HS code setup
• Customer directed to reference slide 11 of WEST team documentation for step-by-step import tax rate configuration

## 4. Key Findings

• WisE system does not maintain Import Tax Rate master data
• WisE-to-WEST interface only transfers Contract master information
• Import duty tax rates must be configured in WEST system's Purchase Order process
• PO item duty rates are determined by Material master HS code duty rate settings
• Missing HS code registration requires PO cancellation and manual recreation

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations

**Final Status**: Case resolved with customer provided clear guidance on import duty tax rate configuration process in WEST system.

**Recommendations**: Customer should configure import duty tax rates directly in WEST PO system using the provided WEST team documentation, specifically following the instructions in slide 11 for proper HS code and duty rate setup in Material master to ensure automatic duty rate reflection in future Purchase Orders.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Good question keyword coverage, supports ground truth keywords

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement
Customer could not locate contract numbers CNTJPN806/CNTJPN808 in the WisE shipping route management system's Shipping Route List and requested assistance in finding this information.

## 2. Solution Summary
The contracts were successfully located by navigating to the specific shipping route CN(DAL) > JP SEA through the Manage Master menu structure in the WisE system.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• Customer reported inability to find contracts CNTJPN806/CNTJPN808 in Shipping Route List
• Support team investigated the WisE shipping route management system
• Located contracts under shipping route code SRCNJPS02 with route description CN(DAL) > JP SEA
• Verified contract details showing active sales contracts between TTC (Nagoya) as buyer and Toyota Tsusho Tianjin as seller
• Provided navigation instructions: Manage Master > Shipping Route > CN(DAL) > JP SEA
• Confirmed contract information accessibility through the specified path

## 4. Key Findings
• Contracts CNTJPN806/CNTJPN808 are active sales contracts in the system
• Shipping route code SRCNJPS02 corresponds to CN(DAL) > JP SEA route
• Contract details include USD2 currency, 3-day export lead time, and delivery to Nagoya, Japan
• Contracts are linked to warehouse TFZ5 and seller section CBK1

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations
The issue was resolved with contracts successfully located and accessible through the proper navigation path. The customer was provided with specific menu navigation instructions to access the contract information in future queries. The case was marked as solved, ensuring the customer can independently locate similar contract information using the Manage Master > Shipping Route navigation structure.

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement

Customer requested addition of two new payment terms in the WisE master system: "30 Days After End Of Delivery Month" and "60 Days After End Of Delivery Month" with specific codes ZSP00005 and ZSP00006 respectively.

## 2. Solution Summary

New payment terms were registered in WisE master system after confirming that existing standard payment terms were not suitable for the customer's requirements.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Customer submitted request via Service Web with attached Excel form requesting two new payment terms in WisE master
• GCC acknowledged receipt and escalated request to technical team for evaluation
• Technical team identified existing WisE standard payment terms as potential alternatives (CRM030D and CRM060D for 30/60 days from end of cargo receipt month)
• GCC contacted customer to verify if existing standard payment terms could be used instead of creating new ones
• Customer confirmed existing payment terms were not applicable and requested creation of new terms as originally specified
• Technical team approved creation of new payment terms with requested codes ZSP00005 and ZSP00006
• GCC completed WisE master registration for both new payment terms
• Customer was notified of completion and requested to verify implementation

## 4. Key Findings

• Existing WisE standard payment terms (CRM030D/CRM060D) were based on "cargo receipt month" rather than "delivery month"
• Customer's business requirements necessitated "delivery month" based payment terms
• New payment term codes ZSP00005 and ZSP00006 were successfully created to meet specific business needs

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations

The WisE master registration was completed successfully with both requested payment terms now available in the system. Customer was advised to verify the implementation and report any issues. No specific preventative measures or long-term recommendations were documented in the source.

context_text:
## Technical Post-Mortem Report

### 1. Problem Statement
Payment terms configured in WisE system with two different settings (BL180D for specific contract numbers and BLM090D for others) were not properly synchronizing to JAST system, which was only receiving and displaying the BL180D payment term for all transactions.

### 2. Solution Summary
The issue was resolved by identifying that JAST uses Interface Mapping with trading partner codes to determine payment terms rather than directly inheriting WisE Contract Master payment term configurations.

### 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• Customer reported discrepancy between WisE payment term configuration (two different terms) and JAST display (single term only)
• JAST helpdesk confirmed they only receive transmitted data and directed investigation to data connection side
• BMO team escalated issue to Global Contact Center (GCC) for technical analysis
• GCC investigated WisE Contract Master payment terms configuration and JAST interface mapping
• Analysis revealed trading partner code A1981960 was registered in current contract
• Verification showed Interface Mapping uses trading partner codes to determine payment terms sent to JAST
• Confirmed that WisE invoice remarks column displays Contract Master payment terms but these are not transmitted to JAST
• Identified that payment terms master registration follows trading partner code A12510 configuration
• Determined that without specification for 1st line export entry number, system defaults to 2nd line 06MGE configuration

### 4. Key Findings
• WisE Contract Master payment terms are displayed in invoice remarks but not transmitted to JAST
• JAST payment terms are controlled by Interface Mapping using trading partner codes
• Trading partner code A1981960 was mapped to single payment term configuration
• System defaults to 2nd line configuration (06MGE) when 1st line export entry number is unspecified

### 5. Final Status & Recommendations
The issue was resolved by clarifying the system architecture where JAST receives payment terms through Interface Mapping based on trading partner codes rather than direct WisE Contract Master settings. For future prevention, ensure trading partner code configurations in Interface Mapping align with desired payment term requirements, and verify export entry number specifications to avoid default fallback behavior.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Good coverage of question and ground truth keywords, and good RAG answer keyword coverage

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement

An invoice failed to register in WEST system due to a GR (Goods Receipt) integration error from WisE to WEST. The specific issue was that Purchase Contract #4400003908 had blank Payment Terms, preventing further processing in WEST and blocking invoice workflow.

## 2. Solution Summary

The issue was escalated to development team via JIRA ticket WEST-60 for Payment Terms configuration on the affected purchase contract.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Customer reported invoice registration failure in WEST system with GR integration error from WisE
• Identified root cause as blank Payment Terms field linked to Purchase Contract #4400003908
• Created JIRA ticket WEST-60 to track the technical resolution
• Escalated issue to development team for Payment Terms entry on the target contract
• Provided JIRA ticket reference to customer for tracking
• Closed customer service case after handoff to development team

## 4. Key Findings

• GR integration from WisE to WEST fails when Purchase Contracts have blank Payment Terms
• Contract #4400003908 was missing required Payment Terms configuration
• Invoice processing in WEST is dependent on complete contract data from upstream systems

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations

**Final Status**: Case closed at customer service level with escalation to development team via JIRA ticket WEST-60 for technical resolution.

**Recommendations**: Not documented in source.

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement

Customer reported a discrepancy in contract JPNMXT005 payment term calculation where July sales should have a September payment date (N+2 calculation based on B/L date), but the JAST system was showing October as the payment date instead.

## 2. Solution Summary

The issue was resolved by directing the customer to correct the payment terms directly in JAST master data rather than modifying WisE master settings.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Customer submitted inquiry regarding payment term discrepancy for contract JPNMXT005 between expected N+2 calculation and JAST system display
• Operations team received and documented the incident with full contract details (Toyota Tsusho Mexico buyer, TTC Nagoya seller, USD currency, N+2 payment terms)
• Technical analysis determined that WisE payment terms are not displayed in purchase orders or invoices
• Support team identified that JAST master data corrections are required for payment term reflection
• Customer was provided with specific documentation link for JAST master correction procedures
• Final response delivered explaining the system relationship between WisE and JAST for payment term processing

## 4. Key Findings

• WisE payment terms do not directly display in purchase orders or invoices
• Payment term discrepancies require correction in JAST master data rather than WisE master modifications
• JAST system maintains separate master data that controls payment term calculations independent of WisE settings

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations

The incident was resolved by clarifying the correct system for payment term modifications. The customer was directed to update JAST master data directly to correct the N+2 payment calculation discrepancy. Documentation was provided via the internal knowledge base link for detailed procedures on JAST master corrections to prevent similar issues in future contract payment term configurations.

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement

Customer requested guidance on where to include HS Codes for export requirements, as the part change interface in WisE system did not display an HS Code column. The issue affected three customers: BRTBD, BRGBR, and BRJOT.

## 2. Solution Summary

The HS Code can be added for each part number in Step 3 of the Modify Contract process under Import Contract management, with different Import TTC offices responsible for different contracts.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Customer reported missing HS Code column in part change interface for export requirements
• BMO Team was assigned to investigate the matter
• Global Contact Center identified that HS Code entry is available in Step 3 "Import Part Info" under Modify Contract
• Customer confirmed visibility of the interface but reported inability to locate specific contracts in TTB Manage Master
• Analysis revealed that BRT was not the Import TTC office for some of the Import Contracts
• Contract ownership mapping was provided showing which Import TTC offices (SGT, JPN, BRT) manage contracts for each customer
• Customer was directed to contact respective Import TTC offices for HS code changes
• Case closure was requested and approved

## 4. Key Findings

• HS Code entry functionality exists in the WisE system under Import Contract modification Step 3
• Contract visibility is restricted based on Import TTC office assignments
• Different Import TTC offices (SGT, JPN, BRT) manage different contracts for the same customers
• Import TTC is responsible for Import Contract HS Codes, Export TTC is responsible for Export Contract HS Codes

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations

The case was resolved with status changed to "Solved." The customer was provided with the correct location for HS Code entry and a mapping table showing which Import TTC office manages each contract. For future HS Code changes, users should contact the respective Import TTC office responsible for their specific contracts rather than attempting to modify contracts managed by other offices.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: High RAG answer keyword coverage and supports ground truth keywords

context_text:
## Technical Post-Mortem Report

### 1. Problem Statement
An error was displayed when adding a master (purchase contract) to the WisE Parts list system. The error specifically occurred when the WisE contract for the exporting country was not properly filled in during the contract creation process.

### 2. Solution Summary
The issue was resolved by clarifying that users should select "New Contract" when the purchase contract is not ready, which functions equivalently to selecting "Purchase Contract."

### 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• **Initial Investigation**: GCC team reviewed the error report and attached Excel file containing error details
• **File Verification**: Identified mismatch between description and attached file, requested correct error-generating file
• **System Behavior Analysis**: Confirmed the error was a legitimate system validation check requiring proper workflow adherence
• **Workflow Clarification**: Verified that users can continue creating import/export sales contracts despite the validation error
• **Solution Guidance**: Provided workaround instruction to select "New Contract" option when purchase contract is not prepared

### 4. Key Findings
• The error represents intended system validation behavior, not a system defect
• WisE system requires exporting country contract information to be completed before adding parts to the Parts list
• "New Contract" and "Purchase Contract" selections function equivalently when purchase contract is not ready
• Import/export sales contract creation can proceed independently of this validation error

### 5. Final Status & Recommendations
**Final Status**: Issue resolved - confirmed as expected system behavior with workaround provided.

**Recommendations**: Users should follow the established workflow by selecting "New Contract" when purchase contracts are not prepared. The system validation is working as designed to ensure proper contract data integrity in the WisE Parts list system.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Good question keyword coverage, supports ground truth keywords

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement

Customer was unable to select purchasing contracts for registered items in the Supplier Parts List when attempting to add additional part numbers to sales contract JPNIDT001. The system only displayed "New Contract" as an option despite having target part numbers registered in the supplier parts list.

## 2. Solution Summary

The issue was resolved by identifying that the customer was attempting to link a 1-to-1 purchasing contract to a non-1-to-1 sales contract, which is not permitted by the system.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Customer reported inability to select purchasing contracts for registered items when adding part numbers to sales contract JPNIDT001
• Support team received incident details including the target sales contract and attached part number list (JPNIDT001(2)_20240503103730.xlsx)
• GCC staff analyzed the contract type compatibility requirements
• Investigation revealed system constraint: standard purchasing contracts cannot be mixed with 1-to-1 purchasing contracts
• Support team requested clarification on whether the target purchasing contract was 1-to-1 type
• Root cause identified: customer was attempting to link incompatible contract types (1-to-1 purchasing contract with non-1-to-1 sales contract)
• Customer confirmed the diagnosis and acknowledged the contract type mismatch

## 4. Key Findings

• System enforces strict contract type compatibility - standard contracts must pair with standard contracts, 1-to-1 contracts must pair with 1-to-1 contracts
• Contract type mismatch prevents selection of existing purchasing contracts in the Supplier Parts List interface
• The limitation applies specifically when adding part numbers to existing sales contracts

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations

The incident was resolved with status "Solved" after the customer confirmed understanding of the contract type compatibility requirement. The customer acknowledged they were attempting to link incompatible contract types. For future operations, ensure contract types (standard vs 1-to-1) are aligned between sales and purchasing contracts before attempting to add part numbers through the Supplier Parts List.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Good coverage of question keywords, supports ground truth keywords

context_text:
## Problem Statement
An error was displayed when adding a master (purchase contract) to the WisE Parts list system, with the system requiring the WisE contract for the exporting country to be filled in before proceeding.

## Solution Summary
The error is a designed system check that can be bypassed by selecting "New Contract" instead of "Purchase Contract" when the purchase contract is not ready.

## Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• Customer reported error when adding purchase contract to WisE Parts list
• Global Contact Center requested clarification on file attachment mismatch with described issue
• GCC confirmed the error behavior is correct system functionality, not a defect
• GCC provided workaround instruction to select "New Contract" option when purchase contract is unavailable
• System allows continuation of import/export sales contract creation using the workaround

## Key Findings
• The error message is an intentional system validation check, not a system malfunction
• WisE system requires exporting country contract information before allowing certain operations
• "New Contract" selection functions equivalently to "Purchase Contract" selection when purchase contract is not prepared

## Final Status & Recommendations
**Final Status**: Issue resolved - confirmed as expected system behavior with documented workaround.

**Recommendations**: When creating import/export sales contracts in WisE, users should select "New Contract" if the purchase contract is not ready, which provides the same functionality as "Purchase Contract" selection. Users should follow the established system check procedures when adding contracts to WisE Parts lists.

context_text:
## Technical Post-Mortem Report

### 1. Problem Statement
TTTJ could not locate purchase contract number JPNCNT807 in the WisE system when attempting to add part number 90183-06030 to sales contract CNTGT506, despite TTC having already added the supplies to the system.

### 2. Solution Summary
The issue was resolved by addressing contract routing problems and ensuring proper 1-to-1 business relationship configuration between the purchase and sales contracts in the WisE system.

### 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• Initial investigation identified that contract CNTGT506 had a broken route causing WisE P/N 9018306030's purchase contract to display as "New Contract"
• Verified that both contracts JPNCNT807 and CNTGT506 were configured as "1 to 1 Business" relationships
• Identified pending master request for part price update (JPNCNT807_天津TG向け補給_90183-06030) submitted by TTC Nagoya requiring approval
• Confirmed that TTC-Japan Export approval and CNT office buyer confirmation were both in "Pending" status
• Instructed that once "New Contract" selection triggers a request to Purchase From party, TTC-Japan Export must complete required registration
• Directed CNT office to modify and update contract master to select the newly registered purchase contract instead of showing "New Contract"
• Verified that contract relationship compatibility was maintained (both contracts must be 1-to-1 for dropdown visibility)
• Confirmed resolution of routing issues and contract visibility

### 4. Key Findings
• Broken contract route in CNTGT506 caused purchase contract display issues
• Master request approval workflow was stuck in pending status at multiple approval levels
• Contract type mismatch (non-1-to-1 vs 1-to-1) prevents contract visibility in dropdown selections
• Registration completion by TTC-Japan Export is prerequisite for contract master updates

### 5. Final Status & Recommendations
The issue has been fully resolved and confirmed by the customer. For future prevention, ensure that contract routing is properly configured before adding new part numbers, verify that contract business relationship types are compatible (both must be 1-to-1), and confirm that all approval workflows are completed before attempting to link purchase and sales contracts in the WisE system.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: High coverage of question and ground truth keywords, and good RAG answer keyword coverage

context_text:
## Technical Incident Report

### 1. Problem Statement
Customer reported that invoice THZA00910 does not display an "Approve" button on the invoice screen in the WisE shipping document system, despite the invoice being submitted and approval requested from manager account.

### 2. Solution Summary
The issue was resolved by confirming that the invoice had already been approved in the system, eliminating the need for the "Approve" button to display.

### 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• Customer reported missing "Approve" button for invoice THZA00910 with screenshot evidence
• Case escalated to BMO Team for investigation
• Global Contact Center accessed WisE system to verify invoice status
• System check revealed invoice THZA00910 had "Approved status" as of 18 Dec 2025 at 02:49
• Approval history confirmed invoice progression from issued status (10 Dec 2025 09:09) to approved status by tossapol@tttc.co.th
• Screenshot evidence provided to customer showing current approved status in WisE system
• Customer notified that invoice approval process was complete

### 4. Key Findings
• Invoice THZA00910 was already in approved status, explaining absence of "Approve" button
• System correctly removed approval interface elements once approval workflow completed
• Invoice approval timeline showed 8-day processing period from issuance to approval
• WisE system properly tracked approval chain through Toyota Tsusho (Thailand) Co.

### 5. Final Status & Recommendations
The case was resolved with confirmation that invoice THZA00910 has approved status and no further action is required. The absence of the "Approve" button was the expected system behavior for invoices that have completed the approval workflow. For future reference, users should check invoice status in the WisE system before assuming approval functionality issues.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: High question keyword coverage, supports ground truth keywords

context_text:
## Problem Statement
A THTBA supplier user reported that the Revised Forecast (FC) information was not displaying correctly in the Supplier Order History screen when using the "Revised FC" filter, requiring specific PO searches to view revised forecast amounts.

## Solution Summary
The issue was resolved by correcting the date range filter to include the supplier-confirmed order date rather than using a later date range that excluded the relevant orders.

## Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• Customer reported that Revised FC screen showed no information when searched without specific PO, but displayed data when PO was specified or "Revised FC" filter was unselected
• Initial analysis suggested the issue was related to date range filtering being set incorrectly (March 24th start date was too late)
• Recommended adjusting date range to start from March 21st to capture PO issued date
• Further investigation revealed the actual reflection timing was based on supplier-confirmed order date (March 21st) rather than PO issuance date
• Provided comprehensive documentation of three order history report types: Customer-only, Supplier-only, and TTC-Group reports
• Clarified that Order History (Supplier) reflects data after supplier confirmation with immediate updates
• Confirmed proper date range filtering resolves the visibility issue for revised forecast amounts

## Key Findings
• Order History (Supplier) reports reflect data based on supplier-confirmed order date, not PO issuance date
• Date range filtering must include the supplier confirmation date to display revised FC information
• Different order history report types have distinct reflection timing and update mechanisms
• Revised FC orders appear with "Confirmed" status and "Revised Forecast" type in supplier reports

## Final Status & Recommendations
The case was resolved with proper date range configuration. The system behavior is working as designed - suppliers should ensure their date range filters include the supplier-confirmed order dates when searching for revised forecast information. Long-term recommendation is to reference the provided order history report documentation for proper filtering and timing expectations across different report types.
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: High coverage of question and ground truth keywords, and high RAG answer keyword coverage

context_text:
## Technical Post-Mortem Report

### 1. Problem Statement
Customer reported that a forecast modification for part number PN 77289-12100 was not transmitted to the supplier, despite the part being registered in Customer Contract (BRKAU001) on September 27 and PIC modifying the forecast on September 30.

### 2. Solution Summary
Confirmed that forecast modifications for new parts added mid-month are technically possible during the monthly additional/forecast order change window, but identified a system limitation where new parts with forecast-only revisions don't appear on PO printouts.

### 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• Customer inquiry escalated to technical team for investigation of missing forecast modification records
• Technical team searched system for forecast modification records related to PN 77289-12100
• No forecast modification records found in system database
• Requested customer confirmation and documentation of forecast modification steps taken
• Customer confirmed PIC issued forecast modification but no screenshots were captured
• Customer questioned whether forecast modification is possible for parts not included in original contract timing
• Technical team confirmed forecast modification capability for new parts during monthly change window (26th to end of month)
• Identified system limitation where PO printouts don't display new parts with forecast-only modifications

### 4. Key Findings
• System limitation prevents new parts from appearing on PO printouts when only forecast is revised
• Forecast data for new parts is visible on order information screen despite PO printout limitation
• Monthly additional/forecast order change timing allows modifications from 26th of month to month end
• No audit trail or documentation was maintained for the original forecast modification attempt

### 5. Final Status & Recommendations
The issue is resolved with confirmation that forecast modifications for new parts are technically supported during the designated monthly change window. A system kaizen is already planned to address the PO printout limitation by displaying new parts with 0 quantity when only forecast is revised. Future forecast modifications should be documented with screenshots for audit trail purposes.

### 6. Business-Specific Terminology Retained
- Customer Contract (BRKAU001)
- PIC (Person In Charge)
- TTC Exp
- Global Contact Center (GCC)
- System kaizen
- Monthly additional/forecast order change timing
usefulness_reason: Supports question or ground truth keywords
rank_reason: Supports question and ground truth keywords

context_text:
## Problem Statement

A customer reported that their approval workflow for price updates was incorrectly sending sensitive pricing information to unauthorized recipients, including unrelated companies abroad, instead of only routing to the designated first approver (shao_shuangshuang@toyotsu-ea.com).

## Solution Summary

The customer was informed that only administrators or managers have permission to modify approval workflows, and they need to contact their office admin to make the required approver changes.

## Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Customer reported approval workflow sending price updates to wrong recipients including external companies
• Support team explained that TTC Contract pricing follows "Buyer-Seller" master principle where seller updates data and buyer confirms changes
• Customer requested guidance on how to change the approver in the workflow
• Support provided attachment "How to modify approver of Approval Workflow" with detailed steps for using Workflow Management function
• Customer reported they could only view the workflow but lacked modification permissions
• Support confirmed that only admin or manager roles can modify Approval Workflow settings, not regular PICs
• Customer acknowledged the resolution and requested case closure
• Support team marked the ticket as "Solved"

## Key Findings

• TTC Contract pricing operates on a "Buyer-Seller" master data model requiring both seller updates and buyer approval
• Approval workflows can only be modified by users with administrator or manager permissions
• Regular PIC (Person in Charge) users have view-only access to workflow configurations
• Workflow Management function provides the interface for modifying approval processes when proper permissions exist

## Final Status & Recommendations

**Final Status**: Issue resolved - customer understood the permission requirements and accepted the solution.

**Recommendations**: Customer should contact their office administrator or manager to modify the approval workflow settings to ensure price updates route only to the designated first approver (shao_shuangshuang@toyotsu-ea.com) and prevent unauthorized access to sensitive pricing information.

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement

A user reported confusion regarding the approval workflow in the WisE system, where an incorrect second approver (siradee@tttc.co.th) was being assigned for selling price change approvals instead of the expected approver (jolyntan@toyotsu.com.sg), despite the WisE system displaying the correct second approver configuration.

## 2. Solution Summary

The issue was resolved by verifying that the user Siradee was registered as an Administrator with access rights to both TTTC and TTAP, enabling proper contract approval functionality.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Initial investigation confirmed that the selling price change approval process was Active, requiring local buyer approval with local PIC as second approver
• Customer provided evidence showing discrepancy between WisE system configuration (jolyntan@toyotsu.com.sg as second approver) and actual approval workflow (siradee@tttc.co.th receiving approval requests)
• Case escalated from OP Team to GCC for further investigation
• APL team requested to conduct root cause analysis
• Verification performed on user access rights and administrator privileges
• Confirmed Siradee was registered as Administrator with dual access rights to TTTC and TTAP systems
• Validated that administrator privileges enabled contract approval capabilities across both entities

## 4. Key Findings

• Siradee was configured as an Administrator with access rights to both TTTC and TTAP
• Administrator privileges allow cross-entity approval capabilities in the WisE system
• The approval workflow was functioning correctly based on the user's elevated access permissions

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations

The case was resolved and marked as "Solved" on 05/23/2024. The approval discrepancy was explained by the administrator-level access rights that enabled Siradee to approve contracts for both TTTC and TTAP entities. No preventative measures or long-term recommendations were documented in the source.

context_text:
## Technical Post-Mortem Report

### 1. Problem Statement
User questioned why they (andrezaki.cahyani.rizal@toyotatsucho.co.id) were assigned as approver for procurement request "EXP-BUY-MIXED-SEP-NOV'24" containing WisE part number 09126BZ010, when other materials in the same request were being approved by a different user (esty@toyotatsucho.co.id).

### 2. Solution Summary
The approval assignment was correct due to missing manager role configuration in the WisE system for Contract No. IDITP002, which caused the workflow to default to TTI administrators as first approvers.

### 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)
• User inquiry escalated from GCC to OP Team for investigation
• OP Team analyzed WisE part number 09126BZ010 configuration under Contract No. IDITP002
• Investigation revealed only PIC role (randi.hidayat@toyotatsusho.co.id) was assigned with no manager role configured
• System defaulted to TTI administrators (andrezaki@toyotatsusho.co.id, cahyani.anggraeni@toyotatsusho.co.id) as first approvers due to missing manager role
• GCC provided explanation to user with alternative resolution path
• User acknowledged explanation and proceeded with approval
• Case marked as resolved and closed

### 4. Key Findings
• WisE part number 09126BZ010 under Contract No. IDITP002 had incomplete role configuration (missing manager role)
• Approval workflow automatically assigns TTI administrators as first approvers when manager role is undefined
• Alternative resolution requires rejection and re-submission of master request to reassign approver

### 5. Final Status & Recommendations
The case was successfully resolved with user acceptance of the current approval assignment. For future prevention, ensure complete role configuration (both PIC and manager roles) is established for all WisE part numbers during contract setup. If approver reassignment is required, follow the rejection and re-submission process for master requests.

context_text:
## 1. Problem Statement

A customer reported that a price revision application (VK Price Revision) for Sales Contract NO. JPNVNH001 submitted on June 13th had inconsistent approval statuses. Some part numbers showed "Approved" status with TTVN approver assignments, while others remained stuck in "Issued" status without TTVN approver assignments. The customer questioned whether different approvers could be registered per part number and why certain items remained in "Issued" state.

## 2. Solution Summary

The issue was resolved by clarifying that approvals are processed at the Customer Contract level with multiple local PICs, and directing the customer to request approval from the correct Vietnamese local persons in charge for the pending item numbers.

## 3. Resolution Process (Step-by-Step)

• Customer submitted initial inquiry with incorrect attachment files showing only Excel file listings instead of relevant screen captures
• GCC staff identified attachment content mismatch and requested correct screen documentation
• Customer provided replacement attachment files with proper documentation
• Technical investigation revealed multiple local PICs registered in Customer Contract JPNVNH001
• Analysis determined approvals are processed by Customer Contract unit rather than individual item numbers
• Identified specific Vietnamese approvers needed: nguyen_huong@vn.toyota-tsusho.com for VNSVC002, VNKYO002, VNSUH500 and minh_ngan@vn.toyota-tsusho.com for VNYVC500
• Customer requested approval from Vietnam side as instructed
• Confirmed pricing logic: pre-approval prices apply if local PIC has not approved
• Customer acknowledged understanding and resolution

## 4. Key Findings

• Approvers are assigned at Customer Contract level, not per individual part number
• Multiple local PICs can be registered within a single Customer Contract
• Secondary approval display issue identified for some item numbers in "Issued" status
• Pre-approval pricing remains in effect until local PIC approval is completed

## 5. Final Status & Recommendations

The inquiry was resolved with status changed to "Solved." The customer understood the approval workflow and initiated the required approvals with Vietnamese local persons in charge. For future prevention, ensure proper screen documentation is provided initially to avoid delays in technical investigation.
